qas.question: What is a muslims life purpose?
What aspect does Alister McGrath argue is important in Christianity?
What does prayer usually include in Islam?
What type of God is the Muslim God?

plausible_answers.text: one has to understand it is an analogy

qas.question: What does Alister McGrath write about the existence of the muslim god?
What kind of role does a personal god play with Alister McGrath?
What is the purpose of life for Christians?
What is an example of an intermediary in Islam?
What are two things the worship of God includes?

context: Prayer plays <b5_0>a significant role<b5_0/> among many believers. Muslims believe that the purpose of existence is <a0_0><b6_0>to worship God<b6_0/><a0_0/>. He is viewed as a personal God and there are no intermediaries, such as <b7_0>clergy<b7_0/>, to contact God. Prayer often also includes <b8_0>supplication and asking <a2_0>forgiveness<b8_0/><a2_0/>. God is often believed to be <a3_0>forgiving<a3_0/>. For example, a hadith states God would replace a sinless people with one who sinned but still asked repentance. Christian theologian Alister McGrath writes that there are good reasons to suggest that <a1_0>a "personal god"<a1_0/> is integral to the Christian outlook, but that <b4_0>one has to understand it is an analogy<b4_0/>. "To say that God is like a person is to affirm the divine ability and willingness to relate to others. This does not imply that God is human, or located at a specific point in the universe."
